title: Re: okay:
content:
Actually technically speaking "weight" is about a force, so it should be in Newton (or something like it).
Kilograms and pounds, or even carats and amus, are really units of mass, so this is not about weighing, but about... mattering?
I weigh about 706 Newton, depending on how long ago I ate, how much, and what I'm doing at the time.

Getting off topic...

title: Re: okay:
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Actually technically speaking "weight" is about a force, so it should be in Newton (or something like it).
Kilograms and pounds, or even carats and amus, are really units of mass, so this is not about weighing, but about... mattering?
I weigh about 706 Newton, depending on how long ago I ate, how much, and what I'm doing at the time.
[hr][/quote]

*sigh*

Actually, no. You cannot use pounds as a intergrade of Newton. Secondly, in the formula "SumF = ma", where that is equated to " SumF = mg + (-T)", and T is tension, normal or whatever in the negative direction (This is becide the point). The main point is, G = to the planet's gravity, ergo your weight changes from planet to planet (Or Gravity field).

Thirdly, those who have yet, or never will, take a physics class usually are incapable of making the distiction of weight as force and wieght as mass.

You must always be specific around me. =P~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: okay:
content:
Well now, lets get physical shall we?

Firstly, alright then, my wight force on Earth is 750N [Actually a bit less, gravity is weaker in Hamilton.]

My mass however is 75Kg, or more specifically about 4'000mol of human.

My estimated density is 1.059g per cubic centimeter and my albedo 0.965.

My melting point is about 325C and I freze regularly.

title: Re: okay:
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Actually, no.[hr][/quote]

Although I'm not sure what your definition of "intergrade" is here exactly... yes you can, and yes, it depends on the surroundings, but that is part of the very definition.
This is not impossible to understand with a little ad hoc lesson either.
I also don't know what you mean with "SumF", so it's hard to comment.
Otherwise I agree with what you said.

I just did some research on Wikipedia, and apparently in English there's something called "apparent weight".
In Dutch this distinction is not made, or at least at school I have been taught both the real weight and apparent weight are simply[quote]Quote:[hr] called "gewicht"...
I have to admit this was confusing back then, and in the end I just settled with the notion that depending on how you look at it, when falling you are either weightless, or not, at the same time.
S[hr][/quote]chrdinger's cat did worse than that, so whatever. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
I'm glad to know there is a distinction after all.

Besides, I disagree with other stuff I learned over there, like current flowing in the opposite direction of the actual movement.
Once you figure something like that out, you should think of a new name, use that, and over time get rid of the old current completely.
Or the fact that it's the kig, not the gram is the SI base unit.
It should've been a unit without the factor 1000.
I realise otherwise the calculations wouldn't work anymore, unless you worked in the factor 1000, but still...
Anyway, hardly big deals.

Sorry for the confusion.

[quote]Quote:[hr]My melting point is about 325C and I freze regularly.[hr][/quote]

Are you sure; when is the last time you melted?Retodon8
You live, you die, you are remembered, you are forgotten. [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Graphics/Keen_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

That cat is nothing more then a metaphor. After all, is not the cat itself an observer?

[quote]Quote:[hr]I just settled with the notion that depending on how you look at it, when falling you are either weightless, or not, at the same time[hr][/quote]

Since weight is a force measured as exerted against something, when falling you are weightless. [Unless you count air friction.] Your are however not massless or inertialess.

[quote]Quote:[hr]I have been taught both the real weight and apparent weight are simply called "gewicht"...[hr][/quote]

Aha! A word in English that has no Dutch equivalent for once! Muhahahaha! Still... makes sense.

title: Re: okay:
content:
You melted in 199?
Even if you missed a 9 or any other digit, this would've been a strange happening.
Do you happen to have any pictures of that PuddleLord version of you, so I don't have to ask about it?
Did you have any extra special powers in liquid form?

The cat being the observer is one of the first things I thought.
Truthfully I'm not quite sure I wrapped my head around the fact that my own thoughts can influence my surroundings.
Although, yesterday I needed to fix a printer, but didn't bring a screwdriver with me.
I didn't feel like walking all the way back, just to get it, and to return again.
So instead I walked outside the room, down the stairs, wished for a screwdriver, didn't find one, walked up again (which wouldn't get me my screwdriver), and crossed somebody in the stairwall who I noticed actually had the right kind of screwdriver (and only that) which he was going to return, and which I was allowed to borrow when I asked about it.
Those kinds of coincidences happen way too often...
Still, it doesn't make much sense.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Since weight is a force measured as exerted against something, when falling you are weightless.[hr][/quote]

Actually (according to Wikipedia, read the 2 relevant articles) that's not the case, depending on whether you're talking about "apparent" or not.
(I am glad I can finally shed my confusement on that.)
I don't know, perhaps there are words for both things in Dutch, but I was never taught about them then.
Maybe it's simply a literall word for word (only 2) translation.

We have the same word for "cousin" and "nephew" for instance, which is annoying.
My brother/sister's son is my "neef" (or "nicht" if female), but my uncle/aunt's son is also my "neef" (or "nicht").
In general I suspect it's rather the other way around, no English words existing for Dutch words, but who knows!Retodon8

title: Hilarious
content:
I'm finding this extremely funny. Only on the PCKF could you talk about pin-up girls, homecomings, newtonian physics, quantum physics and human melting, yet still basically remain on the same topic.
[quote]Quote:[hr]The last time part of me was melted was in january 199 [Don't ask.][hr][/quote]
Now why did you include that last part? Saying you melted will of course make everyone want to ask questions. Can you at least tell what part of you melted? (I tend to get fingers melted, but have managed a shin once, and a forearm. Ouch!)
[quote]Quote:[hr]But yep, thats me, all twice seven years 70Kg of me. [Yes I'm trying to loose weight.][hr][/quote]
You look mighty attractive to me, loose weight if you want, but I don't think you need to. (Not to be a dirty-minded old guy or anything, just a complement.) About 84Kg here, but it's pretty solid.

The cat is indeed sleeping, a cat was used in the metaphor to represent something that could be changed by the contents of the box, but that wasn't observable. Sleeping is, as z-1 implied, intended to indicate that it does not count as an observer. (Pretend it has no awareness of its senses.)

title: Re: PCKF:
content: [quote]Quote:[hr]information will travel between the boxes instantaneously [faster than light][hr][/quote]Is information matter or energy that couldn't travel so fast? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] And what is information anyway? It's just knowledge, and that wouldn't "travel" before you tell someone at the other box what you've found in the box you are standing at (which doesn't need much speed). This is a perfect example of nice looking logic that many of us use for arguments, though we know it's not true, but so misleading [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-mort.gif[/img]

title: Re: PCKF:
content:
You're missing the point. Relativeity tells us nothing, especially information [carried in any form] cannot travel faster than light, to do otherwise would ruin causeality and allow time travel.

The information will travel faster than light, as until one person opens the box there is no way of knowing if the cat is in it or not, and it will appear in each box half of the time. Thus immediately apon opening the box the other box's wave function collapses, information is transmitted and the box ceases to be a quantum object. This is one of the famous contention points between Realativeity and Quantum mechanics.

Don't mess with me, I've read Hawking, and don't want to have to do it again.

A proud member of the signature stealing society
